question.name: Question 1
question.text: What is NOT a function of the regulator?
question.correctans: To temporarily close down a business or enterprise that is found to have breached WHS laws
question.choices: To temporarily close down a business or enterprise that is found to have breached WHS laws|To monitor and enforce compliance with WHS laws|To foster a cooperative, consultative relationship between duty holders and the persons to whom they owe duties and their representatives in relation to work health and safety matters|To advise the Minister on the effectiveness of WHS laws

question.name: Question 2
question.text: What can the regulator require a person to do?
question.choices: To give the regulator information in writing, that the person knows about|To appear before the regulator and give evidence|To produce documents to the regulator|All of the above

question.name: Question 3
question.text: One regulator enforces work health and safety laws in every state and territory. True or false?

question.name: Question 4
question.text: What is NOT a function of a health and safety inspector?
question.correctans: To conduct hourly inspections of workplaces
question.choices: To help resolve work health and safety issues|To review disputed provisional improvement notices|To conduct hourly inspections of workplaces|To attend coronial inquests concerning work-related deaths

question.name: Question 5
question.text: What is a health and safety inspector empowered to do?
question.correctans: Seize any object or document at a workplace that they reasonably believe is evidence of an offence under the WHS Act
question.choices: Order all activities to stop for up to 21 days at any workplace|Arrest a PCBU|Fine any person who has substantially contributed to the commission of a Category 1 offence against the WHS Act|Seize any object or document at a workplace that they reasonably believe is evidence of an offence under the WHS Act

question.name: Question 6
question.text: What is NOT a power of a health and safety inspector?
question.correctans: Seizing, for no reason, any object present at a workplace that the inspector has entered
question.choices: Entering any workplace at any time without prior notice to any person|Requiring any person at a workplace which the inspector has entered to answer any question asked of them by the inspector|Seizing, for no reason, any object present at a workplace that the inspector has entered|Requiring any person at the workplace to give reasonable help to the inspector in carrying out their authorised activities

question.name: Question 7
question.text: What types of notices can be issued if an inspector believes there is a breach of WHS duties?
question.choices: Restitution, prohibition and non-disturbance notices|Non-disturbance, improvement and safety notices|Improvement, prohibition and non-disturbance notices|Restoration, improvement and prohibition notices

question.name: Question 8
question.text: What directions may a prohibition notice issue?
question.correctans: It may direct a PCBU not to carry out an activity until the inspector is satisfied that the WHS risks have been remedied
question.choices: It may direct a person to stop a breach or prevent a likely breach to WHS duties|It may direct a PCBU not to carry out an activity until the inspector is satisfied that the WHS risks have been remedied|It may direct a member of the public to eliminate or minimise health and safety risks arising from exposure to a particular hazard |It may direct a worker to ensure that a site be preserved for as long as the inspector thinks is reasonable

question.name: Question 9
question.text: A non-disturbance notice can only be issued in relation to the site of a notifiable incident. True or false?

question.name: Question 10
question.correctans: A written promise by a person who has breached the WHS Act to take particular measures, as accepted by the regulator
question.choices: The penalty incurred by a PCBU as a result of a WHS breach|A binding direction from the regulator about how a PCBU must adapt work practices to improve work health and safety standards|A written promise by a person who has breached the WHS Act to take particular measures, as accepted by the regulator|A written statement by a PCBU to acknowledge the existence of a WHS breach

question.name: Question 11
question.text: When does an undertaking become enforceable?
question.correctans: When it is accepted by the regulator
question.choices: When the person making the undertaking first informs the regulator about it|When the regulator gives the undertaking to the person named in it|As soon as it is created, unless a later date is specified|When it is accepted by the regulator

question.name: Question 12
question.text: What happens if a person breaches an enforceable undertaking?
question.correctans: The regulator may apply for a court order directing the person to comply with the undertaking and any other order the court considers appropriate
question.choices: The regulator may apply for a court order directing the person to comply with the undertaking and any other order the court considers appropriate|The regulator may issue the person any order it deems appropriate|The regulator may impose any penalty or consequence that is reasonable in the circumstances|There is no consequence for the person, as long as the breach has not created or exacerbated any risks to work health and safety

question.name: Question 13
question.correctans: An order that an offender must take certain specific steps to rectify the consequences of the offence that the court considers the offender able to remedy
question.choices: An order that a person who has been found to be breaching the WHS Act to stop breaching the Act|An order for offenders to publicise the offence they have committed|An order that an offender must take certain specific steps to rectify the consequences of the offence that the court considers the offender able to remedy|An order that an offender must undertake a particular project within a time period specified in the order

question.name: Question 14
question.text: If a person is found guilty of breaching WHS laws, the court can impose a fine or imprisonment on the offender, but not both. True or false?

question.name: Question 15
question.text: Under a court-ordered WHS undertaking, what must an offender do?
question.choices: Comply with any conditions imposed by the court|Avoid committing any offence against the WHS Act during the adjournment |Appear before the court if called to do so during the period of the adjournment |All of the above
